he has suffered from paralysis below the neck he's able to move his head and his left shoulder
i mean he uses a head array or a set of buttons that are mounted around the head rest of his wheelchair to

entire smart home his his home was renovated completely to become a state of the art smart home

image here of kyle actually using a mouth stick with a with a stylus attached to interact with his smartphone
in a similar way the tablet would be actually mounted to the chair using a metal arm and so it would
position the tablet so that he can reach it with this touch this touchscreen mouth stick right
after they renovated his home and did all these interesting interesting modifications and updates
the last thing they did did was mount the tablet to his wheelchair and so what this what the challenge was
that he encountered was he now has all these controls that are accessible through this tablet which all you have to do is attach to
his chair but the mounting point on the chair sits about four inches three or four inches to the right of his wheelbase and so it

just enough clearance for the chair to get through and maybe to turn a little bit so we actually can't when the tablet is attached to that mounting arm
he actually can't fit through the doors that he opens with the tablet so he actually has to have someone come
in to remove the tablet and reattach it when he goes like if he wants to leave his bedroom he actually

to control different devices or at least to have that kind of input in addition to the head array and also
just the real goal for him was to have suitable mounting for his display for his tablet so that it didn't actually change

some of the things that i'll i'll get into these um firms a little bit later but this is demonstrating three
concepts of charitables with this idea of always available interfaces which is common to wearable technologies
where you have access to this device at all times whenever you need it but also tailoring to the specific abilities of the user
which is another common accessibility approach or combining those two and then adding in that this
idea of maintaining the silhouette or the shape of the user and their wheelchair together so maintaining their body shape in these
uh ways as this kind of illustration indicates so i mentioned we went from the kind of
individualized interviews and design sessions where we thought about those individual solutions to working with clinicians and
wheelchair users in a clinical setting to get the perspective of people who work with spinal cord injury patients
uh on the order owner of magnitude of tens to fifteens to hundreds of patients and work through a lot of
these issues in physical therapy and occupational therapy and so we spent four four days doing a
series of focus groups with these clinicians and some and a few wheelchair users
to ideate on what a solution might be for a phone dialer a game controller
in the first case we focused on these specific applications and then from kind of examining the results of that
we moved into a more general space of focusing on how people can input
information into a system and then how can people interact through different kinds of innovative outputs
that we conducted either on four consecutive days with a series of people in and out after we
came out of those focus groups we took those results into individual design sessions focused around the different inputs and
output techniques that arose from that study and we asked individual users to once again think
about how they would configure an ideal solution for them to make their wheelchairs interactive
so if we started off by asking to identify reachable areas on their wheelchairs using a diagram similar to
this one they could identify which areas they could physically reach to interact with some kind of input or some kind of
output we ask them to then configure the inputs and outputs that they would like in those different locations describe
the functionality that they would provide and then rank their preferences for different inputs and output techniques
or related to their configuration and so the result of those uh focus
groups interviews and sections was this kind of rank ordered list of input and output types and the ways that
they might be um attached or configured on the chair and so from the input side wheelchair integrated and wearable
inputs were the most popular removable interfaces which are where the most common at the time
moved to the number three position and then gesture based interfaces which we our definition for gesture
based interfaces with more in-air free gestures so actually being able to gesture in free space open space rather than on a touch
screen or surface and then on the output side head mounted displays which were the most novel thing
at the time the google glass had just been announced and released it was one of chosen for both the novelty and the
potential of having a very private um display that only you could see but interact with in a different way
and then add on screens of the more traditional method and projected interfaces fell to third because there were only
three options there um the projected interfaces presented a lot of potential but at the same time a lot of privacy
implications that people just weren't interested in dealing with they didn't want to have their text messages displayed on a wall next
to them or onto another surface that anyone else could walk by and use
um and so there was the overall high level take away one of the takeaways from that study were these this set of five principles
which i used to guide designing technologies and solutions for wheelchair users that leverage uh the wheelchair and so
the first one is building on this idea of always available so availability um you know device should be always on or always
available at the very least they should maintain the silhouette of the user and their wheelchair the devices should be tailored to
individual abilities we should be considering strongly the familiarity to known devices and systems
which is another kind of usability principle we think about learnability whereas we carry over the positive
effects of prior use of devices but also we should understand kind of the negative implications that devices
have had in the past so for a lot of the technologies that people had used they had negative experiences with touch screens
or negative experiences with gesture-based interfaces which kind of limited their willingness to attempt their willingness to try
new interaction techniques um because of their past experiences with them so in order to you know introduce these we
need to understand the relationship that people currently have with those devices and then finally robustness to different
environments and conditions of use so um one thing i think we can all agree on is that most of us you know
at least pre-pandemic do not spend all of our lives in the same room we're sitting in the same chair um and so in this same context most
wheelchair users despite using the same wheelchair for most of their mobility needs will be
traveling and traversing multiple different environments different weather conditions different homes things like that
and so the biggest enemy to any electronic device right now i think we can also agree is water and so if it rains and you're
out in your fancy electronic wheelchair with all your devices they need to be able to handle that
but what did we do with that so we took those principles and we wanted to instantiate them in some way
and really to build you know what is the first charitable look like um so we took those kind of high
priority ranked preferences for inputs and outputs and came up with the just rest which is
a terrible for integrated control so some of you may recognize this chair or a chair that is similar to this is
that the captain's chair from the starship enterprise i believe this one is from voyager i could be wrong someone who's a bigger

um one of the things that you'll notice or that you'll notice now is that anybody who sits in this chair automatically becomes the captain and

now given to them just by sitting in this chair and so this idea of the captain in command of the ship and
captain of all the functionalities being attached and being centered on this one seat
is kind of what drove kind of the idea of what charitables could be it also
happens to have integrated controls in the exact locations where wheelchair users also specified as
wanting to have those and this can reconfigurable to meet the needs of the particular captain who is running the ship which controls
you one at your fingertips versus farther away from you i'll go back to this image of you know
what to give you kind of an idea of what we're designing for what are we trying to accommodate with this as far as disabilities and accessibility
needs go we wanted to make sure that the people people are using this device which would show and may show a lot of variation in

and so in each of these images if we start at the top left you can see this person with an open palm very loose very loose kind of uh

and so for that person they're doing it with that one finger and sliding forward with their hands staying open the whole time
on the top right you have kind of a loosely clenched fist where they're doing it more with their knuckles person in the bottom right with a very

left where their hand is actually contracted due to other lack of rehabilitation and so they're actually
in a much more awkward position to try to press down on the surface using the top of their finger
but our device needs to be able to uh work in a similar way or in the same way for
all of these folks with these different hand positions and poses until the just rest fsr which is the
longer name or force sensitive resistor is a pressure sensitive input device rather than being capacitive
for touch and gesture input on the wheelchair armrest so ideal location integrated controls
so the idea was to enable users to perform familiar gestures but actually using the surfaces of their
wheelchair which they're already accustomed to rather than having to have a set of switch controls which you would
need to mount multiple or having their smartphone device out at all times um so what this allowed us to do was to
support multiple interactions in a single area making it possible to replace you know two or more switches that would take up
the same amount of space with a single input surface also what this allows us
to do is not to explicitly need to detect individual fingers and instead rely on the pressure being applied to the
surface which allows the users to perform the gestures with different parts of their hand or even using a different kind of
tool in addition to common touch screen gestures that you might think of when we
think of touch gestures like tap swipes and drags slides and things like that or pinch or multi-touch
single touch gestures we also came up with a set of five special gestures specific to the armrest because this is
a form factor that we really want to leverage and get the most out of and so we came up with these five special
gestures the first one being the squeeze gesture where if something a common action you probably do with your arm rest of your
chair if you have one you might squeeze the end of the armrest and we can use that as a deliberate input to the system
to control some functionality the second one which is also one of my favorites is the lift gesture which if you've ever
you know paid attention to the word at the armrest not an arm raised you actually rest your arms on the surface for the majority of the time and
deliberately lift your arms off as an action so we can detect that and use that as an
input to the system as well does this what does this mean when you lift the punch gesture which is by far the
favorite of participants something that you would like to do but cannot do usually with your very expensive smartphone
is to be able to apply a direct and solid force against this armrest and actually be able to measure that force
and understand that it was a punch or very swift swift motion the roll gesture in the
rock gesture the roll being rolling your hand from one side of the armrest to the other and the rock being able to do that
alternating from inside and out
so we followed a similar approach to the previous study where we both involved both individual
wheelchair users and clinicians to gain both an individualized perspective and a broader perspective for multiple
patients or multiple users when we evaluated these we conducted two evaluations one where we specifically
uh explored um the fsr version of the just rest where it's a just a
pressure sensitive armrest-based interface but we also wanted to understand whether just by having the
the inputs in the right location whether that was enough to alleviate some of the issues so it's

placing the the touch screen of the smartphone closer to your fingertips where you need it and having that be integrated would also
be something that's suitable so we wanted to really unders understand that um so we tested each of
these devices and asked participants to rate and describe you know how difficult it was to perform each of the touch screen gestures as

happily for us uh the jeff the fsr version of it actually did end up being the top ranked
um device but in terms of ease of use all four of these devices made it significantly easier for them to perform

and so they went and grabbed a block of foam and tried to all of the different gestures and for you know for

how can we design more inclusive activity monitors for people with differing abilities so there's still a

um but we were seeing especially back when the study was conducted this really low adoption of these technologies among
people with disabilities and so there's there were two schools of thought on this whether it was because
of the affordability of the devices how new they were or whether there were accessibility barriers that specifically
created challenges for people who might benefit the most from these kinds of technologies
so we our approach to this was we started with looking at you know what wearables were out uh what wearables

on we conducted semi-structured interviews with athletes and coaches um i'll get into observations and talk
about the national wheelchair basketball tournament how that fits into this line of work and then development
and testing of actual devices which i mean by which i mean smoke sense so basically this is the result of our
early explorations into the space of wearables for fitness most of the devices that were available at the time were some kind
they looked or worked very similar to the apple watch that you see here most of them had were wrist worn
form factor they had some kind of a screen or at least a light and they have the roughly the same kinds of motion sensors
attached to them so they were able to do the kind of basic motion tracking and step counting
early on we conducted a bunch of these studies and identified a lot of different challenges that
people might have faced with wearable technology designs um especially with respect to uh
wearables uh especially as we consider the differences between different bodies right so the human body is really
an extraordinary thing it's extraordinarily adaptable to change uh whether these changes occur early in
life or later in life our bodies are really able to adapt to changes caused by traumatic injuries or disabilities
but these really these things can really change our body shapes and our physiology so what uh what and how we're able to
adapt is really profound thus making these uh different options a challenge so the first one that we saw
was just in terms of body location and sensing so if you remember the foot pod uh the little device that you might attach to
your shoe which would give you feedback on your steps and your gait your running speed heel strike and all that kind of information
i would like my encouragement on these kind of crude examples but the first example is what if you
don't have a foot to attach the shoe to then you can't put the foot pod on the shoe um
which essentially removes that as an option for step counting and activity monitoring um you might say that the next option is
physiological where you can adapt new sensing types to understand different elements of your body and your
exertion um and analyzing one promising approach would be sweat sensing so actually analyzing the content of your sweat
apparently when you exercise a lot you release certain enzymes in your sweat which can be measured and then can give you feedback on how
much exertion you're experiencing one of the interesting facts about spinal cord injury is a
condition called hypohydrosis which is the inability to sweat below your injury level so if someone
has a very high level injury say a c5 are up here in the neck region below
that injury level they may not have a reduced ability or even inability to sweat which makes temperature regulation very difficult
in terms of sweat fencing if you're wearing the wrist worn sweat sensing device there if your diminished ability to
sweat we can't get a very good signal from your sweat and thus making that technique
ineffective at least in the body location presented despite these very um kind of crude
examples the biggest um barrier that we saw for wearable technology adoption was actually just misperception of the
devices and misperception of what they could do so the first this quote from this wheelchair rugby player
um i really love to use um these devices they track steps and i do not take steps
so if i'm supposed to take ten thousand steps a day i don't take any steps in a day i use my chair i move around
the second one from a hand cyclist mother of three who is also an elementary school teacher so i can
imagine this person is never sitting still never not moving i'm sitting yes but i'm constantly rolling
around i'm always interested to know not steps but how much i'm actually moving around i'm never a mobile this picture is not
of the actual person this is a picture of tatiana mcfadden who is a olympic a paralympic um wheelchair racer
um but you get the point this the people are moving around they're never you know sitting they're never sedentary
really they're not really actually like sitting still um so what's revealed about this is not only that the words and perceptions of
the devices are different but in some cases the actual activities that we're interested in monitoring can also be different which led us to
ask you know what would appropriate solutions in this space do what do they look what would they look like and how would they best be used
and so i have a couple of reasons for why we chose to go with sports there's another a number of different activities we
could have gone with could have gone with everyday activities we cooked on with everyday motion um training but in general
one of the big reasons why we went after sports is if you think about modern day sports especially mainstream sports
they're all driven by metrics whether it's digital metrics or not um they're competitive the engagement in
the physical activity is well motivated so it's not something that we have to deal with the confounding variable of
this person is active on tuesdays and wednesdays or fridays we know that if they're playing the sport they're going to be active at
least while they're playing the sport and they're interested in numbers because that is what drives the sport baseball essentially is just statistics
i don't know if anybody actually plays anymore they think they swing the bat and then they count
similarly with all professional sports that you'll see if you dig far enough so i started to
i decided to start with wheelchair basketball as an example wheelchair sport because of my personal connections with
basketball but also the opportunity to get engaged with the professional organization the national wheelchair
basketball association which runs one of the largest adaptive sports events in the
country bringing together about a thousand wheelchair athletes for a weekend which rivals march madness in terms of content
and competition so you think march madness is spread out over the month of march the
national wheelchair basketball tournament is all of that in a weekend it's about 88 games on friday 80 more games on saturday until
you have three champions in the adult division three champions of the junior divisions
woodrow basketball in general for some background is based on traditional basketball where
people are standing up and running around but adapted for use using a wheelchair so some of the rules are changed
and they're using specialized athletic wheelchairs one of the other really interesting facts about wheelchair basketball is
that it uses the functional classification system which assigns each player a functional a number score for their
functional ability to perform motions required for basketball so someone with a very high level
injury or high level severity of impairment may end up on the 1.0 side of that scale where someone who has very
limited impact to their mobility of their motions maybe a 4.5
and so the way that this plays into competition is that you can't have more than 15 points on the court at any given
time so you have to have a mixture of people with different functional abilities playing on the same team in different
positions so it gives you a sense of kind of equitable competition
so what we did in this space was uh we worked to develop spoke sense and this uh liam here was gracious enough to
allow me to use his image and to pose holding up uh our device as our
official spokesperson for spokes sense um at the tournament um so we conducted these kind of early
studies but over the course of three years we got to explore um the space of interac of the
space of this activity tracking and solutions for wheelchair basketball we did these early studies at the national tournament where we did you
know a few interviews and a large 76-person survey of athletes and coaches
to ask them about their preferences and ideas desires for
devices that they might use or desires for metrics and information that a wearable device may provide
and so in as a result of those interviews and the survey we came out with a set of the
information that people were interested in some of the metrics so they were really interested in movement speed acceleration and distance
they're interested in the number of pushes respiration and breathing and heart rate information so things
related to kind of stamina and fatigue management number of pushes is something that was
available at the time via things like the apple watch but it's still understanding how that
movement how the speed and acceleration actually played out was much more important to them than knowing the
number of pushes you can imagine a sloth push will make you go maybe a couple of inches and a hard push may make you go a couple of feet to
yards or even all the way down the court i think it's also important to point out
for the purposes of the work we were actually thinking we actually expected that what would come out of this would be another risk
worn wearable that these players and things players and coaches would be uh interested in using but it turned out that the form
factor the device was much more important than we expected um they were very interested in something that could
attach to the chair which is good for charitables but um the reason for it was because the
devices themselves the wrist worn devices were mostly be considered um wouldn't be considered permissible in
competition because they would be considered jewelry so they wouldn't actually be able to allow be allowed to wear them during the games when they
